content: Seoul, World Capital of Hypermodernity Michael Hurt Blocked Unblock Follow Following Jan 16 A young man turns the dust-related Zeitgeist into a haute couture style all his own. PART I. KOREA IS GOOD TO THINK Sometimes, I like to write think pieces. Or rather, what I like to call theory-think pieces. But these days, whenever a writer wants to wax wistfully on the unpractically Abstract, or use a vocabulary word not on the USA TODAY, 8th-grade reading level, approved list, or even worse still, construct a compound sentence with more than one dependent clause, angry accusations of being an elitist, out-of-touch, academic navel gazer start flying. People start sharing that link from The Atlantic about the excesses of academic writing or otherwise bemoan the arrogance of writing above the ken of one’s actual audience. I don’t think this way and, as a man positively turned on by Theory and Other Abstract Things (one night even say I’m unapologetically Nerdy by Nature TM), I sometimes write pieces that don’t hold back intellectually or theoretically but which still use prose written in real, everyday English. This doesn’t mean the essay is easy to them through without actively focusing a few neurons on with deliberate effort, though, since this is not one of my goals. I like to write pieces that critically crunch and theoretically parse Korean culture for fun and intellectual profit. I like it best when the essay works along the lines of how famed anthropologist Leví-Strauss said of his anthropological study of the Bororo people of Brazil that “animals are good to think.” I already explained this in a previous Korea Times piece this way: The point when Lévi-Strauss wrote this was that the significance of animals on a totem pole was not that they tasted good and hence warranted being graven into wood for all to see in the same way we see happy cartoon pigs marching off their own slaughter on bright signboards for sampgyeopsal restaurants in this culture, but rather that for the people who carved animal faces as totemic objects, they were actually good ways to think about things in life, almost like an life maxim made through an animal face. An easy way to think about it would be “In business, be a fox. Think foxy,” coupled with a picture of a fox as your company mascot. In a culture that produces totem poles, the way to understand the animals engraved there is as symbols with which to think about life. The way I approach “Korea,” in all its sociological and cultural complexity, is as a fascinating barrage of ethnographic data, case studies, and examples of global things and ideas that are being either uniquely developed here either or are firsts unto themselves. And what makes Korea especially interesting. is the fact that Korea does very little by way of being absolutely, categorically first in things, but is more marked by its incremental alterations and additive iterations of things. Take K-POP, for example. Few could effectively argue that K-POP doesn’t have its own recognizable aesthetic, because people around the world instantly recognize K-POP (or even Korean style) instantly, from Malaysia to Micronesia, Angola to Argentina. But few would deny where the elements of the musical style come from — western boy and girl bands, hip-hop, R&B, electronica, rap, and trap music. A Vietnamese take on the K-POP video, combining the conventions and clichés of both K-DRAMA and K-POP forms. Despite being filmed on Jeju Island, it’s Vietnamese…yet also unmistakably Korean. K-POP is iteratively creative, even if it is not generatively so, as in “from scratch,” as mama used to make. I’ve made this point before, and this isn’t the point in this essay. What I am trying to express as an example here is that Korean cultural examples are good to think about greater theory *with*, are good as thinking fodder. It is this way that “Korea” can be interesting to people not directly concerned with Korean things, the place, or its people. And that brings us to the topic at hand — that of “hypermodernity.” But before getting there, it would be useful to talk about “modernity” and “postmodernity” first, which are both terms people use a lot but also usually don’t understand, in the same way that many people talk about The Scarlet Letter but actually haven’t read it. This is why Korea is a great case to write a think piece around but not with the goal of talking about *Korea* per se but as fodder for talking about aspects of *modernity*. PART II. MODERNITY AND BEYOND!!! Thw idea of “modernity” generally gets tossed around in the word “postmodernity”, which generally finds usage in its origins as a genre of art. So what is “modern” vs. “postmodern”? If we talk about genres of music, for example, the traditional categories might be categories you’d find in the record store of the pre-1990s, in sections of so-called “classical,” rock, gospel, R&B ballads, country, and so forth. Despite the problem of some of these categories falling into the definition itself, they are useful for the sake of discussion. These are the traditional, “modern” categories, of classification, produced for purposes of easier commerce and control. In the same way, traditional social categorizations in modern societies exist for the convenience of the economy and social control. “Girl”, as many scholars have argued, are a recent creation of the need to have a social category between a female child and a full-grown woman. In pre-modern times, a female child often became a woman through marriage (and all too often, not by choice). After all, the median age of marriage in many premodern societies across the world from Joseon Korea to Puritan America was thirteen. There was no such thing as the social category of the “teenager” until the new modes of the economy and social life required them. Then, in more developed capitalist societies with new things such as disposable income and the idea of “leisure”, “girls” came to define a market , a group of people to sell things and ideas to.
title_html: Seoul, World Capital of Hypermodernity
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Deconstructing Korea
Sign inGet started

Seoul, World Capital of Hypermodernity

Michael Hurt
Jan 16

PART I. KOREA IS GOOD TO THINK

Sometimes, I like to write think pieces. Or rather, what I like to call theory-think pieces. But these days, whenever a writer wants to wax wistfully on the unpractically Abstract, or use a vocabulary word not on the USA TODAY, 8th-grade reading level, approved list, or even worse still, construct a compound sentence with more than one dependent clause, angry accusations of being an elitist, out-of-touch, academic navel gazer start flying. People start sharing that link from The Atlantic about the excesses of academic writing or otherwise bemoan the arrogance of writing above the ken of one’s actual audience.

I don’t think this way and, as a man positively turned on by Theory and Other Abstract Things (one night even say I’m unapologetically Nerdy by Nature TM), I sometimes write pieces that don’t hold back intellectually or theoretically but which still use prose written in real, everyday English. This doesn’t mean the essay is easy to them through without actively focusing a few neurons on with deliberate effort, though, since this is not one of my goals. I like to write pieces that critically crunch and theoretically parse Korean culture for fun and intellectual profit. I like it best when the essay works along the lines of how famed anthropologist Leví-Strauss said of his anthropological study of the Bororo people of Brazil that “animals are good to think.” I already explained this in a previous Korea Times piece this way:

The point when Lévi-Strauss wrote this was that the significance of animals on a totem pole was not that they tasted good and hence warranted being graven into wood for all to see in the same way we see happy cartoon pigs marching off their own slaughter on bright signboards for sampgyeopsal restaurants in this culture, but rather that for the people who carved animal faces as totemic objects, they were actually good ways to think about things in life, almost like an life maxim made through an animal face. An easy way to think about it would be “In business, be a fox. Think foxy,” coupled with a picture of a fox as your company mascot. In a culture that produces totem poles, the way to understand the animals engraved there is as symbols with which to think about life.

The way I approach “Korea,” in all its sociological and cultural complexity, is as a fascinating barrage of ethnographic data, case studies, and examples of global things and ideas that are being either uniquely developed here either or are firsts unto themselves. And what makes Korea especially interesting. is the fact that Korea does very little by way of being absolutely, categorically first in things, but is more marked by its incremental alterations and additive iterations of things.

Take K-POP, for example. Few could effectively argue that K-POP doesn’t have its own recognizable aesthetic, because people around the world instantly recognize K-POP (or even Korean style) instantly, from Malaysia to Micronesia, Angola to Argentina. But few would deny where the elements of the musical style come from — western boy and girl bands, hip-hop, R&B, electronica, rap, and trap music.

K-POP is iteratively creative, even if it is not generatively so, as in “from scratch,” as mama used to make. I’ve made this point before, and this isn’t the point in this essay. What I am trying to express as an example here is that Korean cultural examples are good to think about greater theory *with*, are good as thinking fodder.

It is this way that “Korea” can be interesting to people not directly concerned with Korean things, the place, or its people.

And that brings us to the topic at hand — that of “hypermodernity.” But before getting there, it would be useful to talk about “modernity” and “postmodernity” first, which are both terms people use a lot but also usually don’t understand, in the same way that many people talk about The Scarlet Letter but actually haven’t read it.

This is why Korea is a great case to write a think piece around but not with the goal of talking about *Korea* per se but as fodder for talking about aspects of *modernity*.

PART II. MODERNITY AND BEYOND!!!

Thw idea of “modernity” generally gets tossed around in the word “postmodernity”, which generally finds usage in its origins as a genre of art. So what is “modern” vs. “postmodern”? If we talk about genres of music, for example, the traditional categories might be categories you’d find in the record store of the pre-1990s, in sections of so-called “classical,” rock, gospel, R&B ballads, country, and so forth. Despite the problem of some of these categories falling into the definition itself, they are useful for the sake of discussion. These are the traditional, “modern” categories, of classification, produced for purposes of easier commerce and control. In the same way, traditional social categorizations in modern societies exist for the convenience of the economy and social control.

“Girl”, as many scholars have argued, are a recent creation of the need to have a social category between a female child and a full-grown woman. In pre-modern times, a female child often became a woman through marriage (and all too often, not by choice). After all, the median age of marriage in many premodern societies across the world from Joseon Korea to Puritan America was thirteen. There was no such thing as the social category of the “teenager” until the new modes of the economy and social life required them. Then, in more developed capitalist societies with new things such as disposable income and the idea of “leisure”, “girls” came to define a market, a group of people to sell things and ideas to.

  • Michael Hurt

    A visual sociologist writing, teaching, and shooting in Seoul since 2002.

  • Deconstructing Korea

    A theoretical consideration of Korean pop culture and society.

    • Deconstructing Korea
    A theoretical consideration of Korean pop culture and society.
